title: 105_hr3032
content: The Act titled "Construction Subcontractors Payment Protection Enhancement Act of 1998" mandates additional responsibilities for the Administrator for Federal Procurement Policy. The Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act is amended to establish Government-wide policies for timely payment of contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers. The Federal Acquisition Regulation implements statutes and policies ensuring prompt payment to contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers, including the Prompt Payment Act, the Miller Act, and the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act of 1994. The Federal Acquisition Regulation will be revised to implement amendments made by the Act within 120 days of enactment, with a 60-day public comment period. Final regulations will be published within 180 days of enactment and will be effective 30 days after publication. Additionally, related amendments to the Miller Act will be made. The Miller Act will see improvements in payment bond protection, with the amount of the payment bond now equaling the performance bond. Progress payments will also be protected under the Act, ensuring payment within seven days after completion. The Miller Act is amended to ensure payment for progress payments within seven days after the due date, extending payment bond protection to all subcontractors and suppliers. Suppliers under the Miller Act are further amended to ensure payment bond protection for subcontractors and suppliers. Amendments include changes in language regarding performance and supply responsibilities. Notice of a lawsuit must be given to the contractor within 90 days. The Miller Act is amended to ensure payment bond protection for subcontractors and suppliers. A notice of a lawsuit must be given to the contractor within 90 days. No waiver of protection under the Act is valid unless in writing after the suit can be initiated. Service of payment bond claims is modernized. The Miller Act requires written waivers for bond validity. Service of payment bond claims is updated to allow delivery through various means. The Miller Act is amended to allow delivery of payment bond claims through various means, including electronic delivery. Additionally, a new subsection is added to prevent dismissal of suits filed before the expiration of a period. The Miller Act is amended to allow electronic delivery of payment bond claims and prevent dismissal of suits filed before the expiration of a period. The Miller Act is amended to allow electronic delivery of payment bond claims and prevent dismissal of suits filed before the expiration of a period. Additionally, a court may award court costs, attorneys' fees, and interest to the prevailing party in a suit under this section if the suit is deemed frivolous or groundless. The Miller Act allows for electronic delivery of payment bond claims and prevents dismissal of suits filed before a certain period. Courts may award court costs, attorneys' fees, and interest to the prevailing party if the suit is frivolous or groundless. Interest awarded is calculated from the date of the claim to the date of payment using applicable interest rates. Interest awarded under this subsection is calculated from the date of the claim to the date of payment using applicable interest rates from the Prompt Payment Act. The contracting officer is responsible for obtaining the payment bond required under the Miller Act. The Miller Act (40 U.S.C. 270a) is amended to require the contracting officer to obtain and maintain the payment bond for a contract. Failure to do so may result in a lawsuit and court intervention. The Miller Act is amended to require contracting officers to maintain payment bonds for contracts. If a court finds that the required bond is not in effect due to the officer's negligence, the person bringing the suit may petition to sue the United States for the amount they would have sued for originally.
